contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} '''Drill''' is stout durable [[cotton]] fabric with a strong bias (diagonal) in the [[weaving|weave]].<ref name="FM1"> {{Cite web | url=http://www.fabrics-manufacturers.com/drill.html | title=Drill Fabric | work=Fabrics Manufacturers | accessdate=28 March 2010 }}</ref> It can be used unbleached, although it is more often [[Bleach (chemical)|bleach]]ed or [[dye]]d.<ref name="FM1"/> ==Use in clothing== [[Image:SPF uniform khaki.jpg|thumb|150px| Antique khaki police uniform at Jurong Police Division Headquarters]] Light weight drill is used in clothing items such as [[shirt]]s, [[safari jacket]]s, [[blouse]]s, and [[sportswear (activewear)|sports clothing]].<ref name="FM1"/><ref> {{Cite news | url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rbIKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Xk0DAAAAIBAJ&dq=cotton%20drill%20sail&pg=4568%2C1013910 | title=Maids Go Angling in Cotton Drill and Sail the Sea in Hopsacking | last=Kerr | first=Adelaide | date=4 May 1938|work=St. Petersburg Times | pages=26 | accessdate=28 March 2010 | location=St. Petersburg, FL, USA }}</ref> The heavier weights were often used in corsets,<ref> {{Cite web | url=http://www.sharonburnston.com/othercenturies.html | accessdate=2010-03-28 | title=Portrait Gallery: Other Centuries }}</ref> and are commonly used in work clothing and uniforms.<ref name="FM1"/> The most common use of drill in [[uniform]]s and casual wear is in the form of [[khaki]]. Strictly speaking, khaki is a tan color, and the word comes from the [[Hindi]] "khak", meaning the color of dust. Troops of the British Empire during its occupation of India wore uniforms of a white cotton drill. During the 1840s it was discovered that dying this drill to a tan closely matching the color of the dusty surroundings resulted in an effective camouflage. The fabric soon became a popular material for military uniforms, and, in the United States following [[World War II]], as veterans returned to college campuses, it became popular in casual dress as well.<ref name="NYT1"> {{Cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/22/magazine/khaki.html | date=27 March 1987 | accessdate=2010-03-28 | title=KHAKI | newspaper=New York Times | first=G. Bruce | last=Boyer }}</ref> Heavy cotton drill is widely used for making cooks' uniforms (chefs' wear) because it is thick enough to protect the wearer from heat.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} ==Other uses== Drill is a versatile fabric that has been used in a variety of applications. Boat sail drill is a light weight unbleached drill used to make [[sails]] for sailing craft.<ref name="FM1"/><ref name="PS1"> {{Cite journal | last=Taylor | first=Stillman |date = June 1916| title=How to Build and Sail a Small Boat-II | journal=Popular Science | volume=88 | issue=6 | pages=929 | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=hyYDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA930&lpg=PA930&dq=boat+sail+cotton+drill&source=bl&ots=u2XiFxI91S&sig=dvDusy8Ha4tx1MNjJ5tGE4xTxS0&hl=en&ei=frmvS7-lI8KAlAepge2HAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAUQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=boat%20sail%20cotton%20drill&f=false | accessdate=2010-03-28 }}</ref><ref name="DM1"> {{Cite journal | url=http://www.duckworksmagazine.com/07/howto/retro/index.htm | title=Retro Tech Sails | last=Booth|first=Bob | work=Duckworks Magazine | accessdate=28 March 2010 }}</ref> Although [[Cotton duck|duck]] (canvas) was more commonly used for these purposes,<ref name="VA1"> {{Cite news | url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Po8nAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mFIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1093,778891&dq=cotton+drill+sail&hl=en | title=Cuero Secretary Asks President to Visit Turkey Trot | last=Carrington | first=J. C. | date=26 November 1926 | work=The Victoria Advocate | pages=4 | accessdate=28 March 2010 }}</ref> drill has also been used to make tarpaulins, tents, awnings and canopies,<ref> {{Cite journal | journal=Daily Southern Cross | volume=XXI|issue=2378|pages=7 | url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=DSC18650304.2.23.5 | accessdate=2010-03-29 }}</ref> but the use of both fabrics has been supplanted in modern times with synthetic fabrics. Like duck, drill is used as a covering for furniture and cushions.<ref name="DIY1"> {{Cite news | url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/house-and-home/property/ask-alice--about-cast-iron-guttering-and-decorating-tips-405599.html | newspaper=The Independent | title=Ask Alice: About cast iron guttering and decorating tips | fate=2006-050-28 | accessdate=2010-03-29 | location=London | date=28 June 2006 }}</ref> ==References== <references/> {{fabric}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Drill (Fabric)}} [[Category:Woven fabrics]] {{Textile-stub}} [[io:Kutio]]
